Articles.Content:
Hi everyone,

Thoughts on the past are in spoiler.  Point of the post is below.
 

Spoiler

As sad as I am re 'losing' my $NZ90 from the start of 2023... that feeling actually occured as my hope for accelerating improvements and functionality from updates diminished, much like a realising i had mucked up staging or I was 1000ms of deltaVee short of reaching orbit.  I kept my money in initially as a show of support for the dev studio to not see it as a loss and give up.. it was a investment risk, not a guaranted return.

TBF my play time has been quite low as modded KSP1 hits all the buttons for me.  I was underwhelmed by the UI choices.  My KSP adjacent child thought the dotmatrix fonts were gnarly (not in a cool way).

Multiplayer doesnt hold much interest for me as that is not the type of gamer I am, with odd time oppurtunities for play.  Storyline is also not really what interests me, aside from explore lore.  The idea of being encouraged to follow a storyline to go interstellar have have a story wasn't what I wanted.  Aliens? Meh.  Unless they were unlockable as a new type of character instead of kerbals, then what would be the point?

I've been thinking about what HarvesteR said in his MattLowne interview and other comments from LGG et al. in the ShadowZone interview as well.

A Kerbal Colony Program would be a new start, way forward, even prequelish?  The story line lore could be colonies existed in the past but in game establishes no reason these were abandoned, but ruins can be Easter eggs to find.  The game is set after an eon when kerbals start to rebuild a space program initially with what is found on the side of the road.

Game play wise, the KCP should be a zoning city builder type game, kind of like Boca Chica but without the locals.  You starting with zoning accomodation, a VAB and a launchsite .  You select a landscape where you then zone areas for launch sites, buildings, etc.  There are some sort of investment costs, perhaps based on rep or number of workers. Procedural building types perhaps?  You need infrastructure, houses, amenities, R&D, VAB, Launch pads.  Workers are a resource. More workers, faster builds, but you manage requests for jobs against ability to house workers.  Speed of rocket builds, reasearch etc based on number of workers and resources.  Don't do much building or reasearch, or it gets too crowded, workers go away.

You can even select WHERE on Kerbin you locate the KSC.

How to get rep, show you are doing something... build sounding rockets, orbital rockets etc.  Build a racetrack and test rovers.  Using parts should contribute to science/research points too, but cumulatively somehow.

Colonies elsewhere would work in the same way.  You land, and start zoning.  Once buildings are set then you have to attract workers for a colony.  There is always a minimum number of workers who just want to be there, but using a colony more will mean more workers will want to go...

But the zoning mechanic is like a first step.  Building rockets is a second step.  You should be able to fly, drive around your KSC.  For an Early Access possibility, start the colony on the Mun. Focus on getting this mechanic good without having to worry about atmosphere (or planes). Add in Kerbin and other planets in milestone update so that you have the atmosphere stuff to deal with.  Add in other planets even later.  R&D colonies by Easter eggs should be bonues for research and attracting workers.

Anyway, my thoughts on this.  Peace.

Edited May 25 by theJesuit
